item.title: micro:bit v1 with yotta - removing build warnings
item.description: problem Running yotta build with the micro:bit v1 C tools produces screenfulls of depreceation warnings, such as: warning: dynamic exception specifications are deprecated in C++11 [-Wdeprecated] This makes it hard to find the error messages with the reason why the build failed. solution Tell the C++ compiler not to include depreceation warnings. instructions Add the compiler flag -Wno-deprecated to the CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS_INIT options in the file toolchain.cmake. File location: <project>/yotta_targets/bbc-microbit-classic-gcc/CMake/toolchain.cmake>/yotta_targets/bbc-microbit-classic-gcc/CMake/toolchain.cmake Line before:

item.title: Eclipse, yotta, C/C++ and the BBC Micro:bit
item.description: With the help of the excellent instructions at the link below I set up Eclipse with yotta to compile C code for the BBC micro:bit under Linux: http://flames-of-code.netlify.com/blog/microbit-cpp-3/ I get the debugger window to come up, but have not yet used this feature in anger. The writer, achary, clearly knows more about Eclipse and embedded programming than I do. I got a little stuck at a couple of stages so created this page to pass on my solutions.

item.title: Setting up yotta and C with the BBC Micro:bit by modifying the examples directory
item.description: I set up to program the BBC Micro:bit (which I’ll call the microbit from now on) in C/C++ under Linux. I’ve been using micropython to program the boards up to now, but want to leverage the increased performance that using C can give and some of the C libraries that are available for e.g. encryption. There is good documentation on the Lancaster University microbit github page: https://lancaster-university.github.io/microbit-docs/ I installed the offline tools as I spend a lot of time working at sea where you can’t always rely on having an internet connection.
